abstract.p: Letter from State Sen Seymour P Lachman disputes Clyde Haberman's July 19 column on New York State's hate crimes law

block.p: I take issue with Clyde Haberman's July 19 NYC column, ''A Moment to Rethink Hate Crimes Legislation.'' The laws do not punish bigotry, thought or speech. Rather, they increase the penalties where a criminal intentionally selects the victim based on group membership, whether perceived or actual.

I take issue with Clyde Haberman's July 19 NYC column, ''A Moment to Rethink Hate Crimes Legislation.'' The laws do not punish bigotry, thought or speech. Rather, they increase the penalties where a criminal intentionally selects the victim based on group membership, whether perceived or actual.

Hate crimes laws punish people for actions and the motivation for those actions. The laws also recognize that some crimes are more egregious than others, a concept we have also applied to crimes committed in and around schools and against police officers.

The question of the accused criminal's intent in selecting the victim is for the jury to determine. In the parking space dispute discussed by Mr. Haberman, the assault was not prosecutable as a hate crime because the victim was not selected on the basis of his religion. I trust that the prosecutors, judges and juries of New York State will apply the law only in appropriate cases.
SEYMOUR P. LACHMAN State Senator, 22nd District Brooklyn, July 21, 2000
